ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual discussion section + pre recorded lecture
None
Virtual discussion sections
recorded lecture, live section
Virtual discussion sections
Recorded lecture and virtual seminar.
It was a combination of asynchronous recorded lectures (2x a week) and live, smaller discussion sections once a week.
Weekly Discussion Section (Online)
recorded lecture with live section once a week
Live virtual check-in sessions with Professor Botsmanvery fun!
N/A
I really enjoyed the prerecorded, high-quality lectures paired with weekly discussions sections.
virtual section recorded lecture movies
Virtual discussion and recorded lectures.
Synchronous section
Recorded lecture and discussion section.
recorded lecture + section
Recorded lecture and virtual section discussions.

In addition to the asynchronously recorded lectures, we had a live, weekly section that met to discuss the week's readings and lectures. Professor Botsman also held two informal "check-in sessions" during the semester to just chat with him, give feedback, and let him know how the semester was going.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel like I have a really solid understanding of historiography and Japanese history up to 1915, and a good introduction to East Asian geopolitics
I learned how ancient Japanese history affect the 19th Century Japanese society, and that helped me better understand East Asian dynamics that led to WWII.
More insight into the history of early modern Japan

Understanding of radical development of Japanese society over the course of the 19th century. Improved ability to perform primary source analysis. Improved writing skills, including of historiography.
I learned a lot of Japanese History from the 1600s to the early 1900s. The class also taught how to think like a historian and to analyze primary documents.
Overview of Tokugawa and Meiji period.

Gained knowledge of the growth of Japan and the international relations formed in the last two centuries. This class gave me great insight into how Japan had developed, socially, economically, and culturally, and what makes it the country that it is today. 
I improved my skills in reading historical primary sources and being able to participate in discussion with respect to the context of the time, and how it has impacted Japan long-term. This class definitely made me think about the role of women in Japanese society, and if/how we can compare it to the US.
Japan history. Analysis of primary source docs

History of Japan from the Tokugawa to the Meiji period. You'll learn how to think critically about Japanese history and historiography and primary sources, and the foundation of current affairs in East Asia today.
I learned a lot about the events that took place in Japan during the late Tokugawa and Meiji era.

I learned to how analyzing historical documents by asking myself who wrote it, why, and for which audience as well as to consider the illuminating historical context of the text. I also learned different ways of interpreting history and how works of historiography can affect the ways in which we view history.
A good understanding of a period of Japanese history and how nuanced all historical developments during this time were.
This course is a pretty exhaustive overview of Tokugawa/Meiji Japan, beginning with the consolidation of power by the bakufu and ending right around the early 1900s.
I learned Japanese history, as well as increased my ability to analyze a primary source.

This was my first history course, and I enjoyed it quite a lot!

The course was a self-contained  presentation and contextualization of 19th century Japan. 

Many of the historical insights we discussed in this course can also be readily applied to understand the modern international stage.
really fascinating course about japans complicated history often disregarded by Americans
I learned about Japanese History and how to approach history generally.
A very broad sweeping understanding of the Meiji Restoration
I learned about the history of Japan and their relations with other countries. I also learned a little bit about their culture.
History of Japan from about 1800 - 1905 (Wide variety of topics)

As a History major focusing on European cultural history, I was unfamiliar with the basics of Japanese culture and history during the eighteenth-twentieth centuries. It was fascinating to think about the ways in which cultural isolation from the West for many centuries affected the nature of Japan, and how its renewed contact with Western countries transformed it rapidly into a modernized, imperialistic nation.

I learned about how Japan went from an isolated, feudal society, to a unified one under a centralized government under the Tokugawa, to a an imperialistic and modern one under the Meiji. Professor Botsman challenged many of my existing preconceptions and notions of Japan's modernization and included a ton of nuances in his lectures that gave me a comprehensive understanding of the period. I not only learned about key players, events, and trends in Japan's history, but also about the connections these figures had to Yale during the period. Outside of lecture, I got a chance to look at primary and secondary source documents to better contextualize the readings, and also learn how to read historical documents using a four question framework. Finally, Prof Botsman even explained a little bit as to how these events led to the creation of universities and other major buildings in contemporary Japanese society today.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was easily the best course I took this semester and one of the best courses I've ever taken at Yale. The professors and TFs actually really cared about student engagement and took the time to really set everything up for remote learning. The video lectures were super engaging and edited so it was easy for non-Japanese speaking students to take notes on Japanese terms, and the handouts were really good and helpful but not so detailed that they would discourage note taking. Also had the most well-organized Canvas of any class I've taken.

I loved Professor Botsman's videos and his attempts to engage with the students through personal interactions.  I thought that sections could have been outlined better by our TA to help us better prepare.
Everything was great. Maybe would have preferred more of a direct linkage between the primary source texts we discussed in seminar and the historical developments described in lecture.

The lectures were well organized and very interesting. It was useful to be able to watch the lectures whenever free since they were recorded. I would recommend some more visuals be added to the lectures.

Strengths: the worksheet to accompany the lectures was very helpful to following the lecture, the length of the readings was manageable, sections were very helpful, the lectures were excellent and cinematographically impressive

Weaknesses: the release of the Thursday lecture was often too late to be seen before section

One strength is the professor. Professor Botsman was so passionate about the subject and a wonderful lecturer. He transitioned so well to this format, his video lectures were fun to watch. 
Another strength was the readings. The readings we did were so interesting as they applied to that week's lectures, but also brought very new information into the picture. 
One weakness, which we cannot control, was the fact that I couldn't learn this in-person or through a live lecture. But, I do think the pre-recorded lectures were great.
Great teacher. Good content. Too many assignments that felt unnecessary

Prof. Botsman is a charismatic public speaker and really understands that this course happened in an unusual semester. Strengths are Prof. Botsman's lectures, while a weakness could be that this is a survey course, so I wish we had gone in more depth into some of the topics. But at the same time, it was really great and crucial (I think) to cover as much time as we did, so I totally understand the tradeoff that had to be made. I haven't taken any other classes on Japan or Japanese history at Yale, but I'd be down to take another one of Botsman's classes.

The quality of the lectures was very good and Professor Botsman did a very good job preparing material and information for the lectures he posted. My only concerns were that sometimes the readings for the week would be uploaded late and that I think having a rubric for some assignments would have been helpful.

Strengths: Professor Botsman, absolutely. This man is a gem and he put so much effort into the recorded lecturesthey were super well filmed, snappy, engaging, and full of fun effects/pictures. Genuinely looked forward to watching them every week. Workload is manageable, though the course is a bit frontloadedafter midterm, there's not really anything due until the final. Few, if any, weaknessesthere was a bit of uncertainty about expectations (re length, style, etc.) for the first two-ish assignments, but this was quickly cleared up after being brought to Prof. Botsman's attention. Teaching team was wonderful. Would highly recommend.
I enjoyed this course

Strengths: really loved the pre-recorded lectures + small-sized discussion sections, Alex was an awesome TF and Prof Botsman was a great lecturer 
Weaknesses: I wasn't really sure how much to read into the secondary readings, so I sometimes skipped them entirely. Since some of these secondary readings are quite long, it would be helpful to point out specific sections that we can skim to better understand the primary discussion topic.
grading is a bit unnecessarily tough on seemingly simple quick assignments, but the assignments themselves are pretty fair and the lectures are highly entertaining, botsman is a fantastic lecturer
More themes + concise focus instead of a general survey of everything.
Professor and TAs are really good. Material could be dry, especially because it was all in lecture form.
I liked how the course was recorded and that we could look back on the lecture whenever we wanted to.

Strengths: Professor Botsman is superb. He's really passionate about his subject as well as sharing his knowledge with others, and it really comes across in his lectures. The recorded format also provided an advantage in terms of flexibility, and I never found myself bored watching the lectures. The TFs in this course (at least my TA Alex) was amazing and super helpful and flexible. If you have even a modicum of interest in Japan's history from 1800-1900, I would highly recommend.

Weaknesses: None really. Maybe a final exam + a final paper can be a lot during finals period, but to be fair, during the semester, there wasn't that much work, so just something to keep in mind. The grading is pretty hard, but you never feel like it was unfairly graded -- it just gives you insight into what true top quality historical analysis.

Recorded lectures were very good! They were smooth and well-presented, and always engaging. The one thing that could improve is the reading load leading up to the second paper, which was quite heavy. If I hadn't worked a week ahead of the syllabus, I would not have been done with the required reading for that paper in time to write it.

Strengths - Prof Botsman, interesting content and lecture format, good section leaders. 

Weaknesses - The first assignment, a historical document analysis, would have massively benefited from a sample paper to show the type of work expected. Prof Botsman picked up on this for the remaining assignments though and it wasn't an issue, but that was a bad way to start what was a great class during the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Professor Botsman's video lectures are what every virtual lecture should aspire to be. 

My only note is that as an off-campus student, it was really hard to get some of the books that aren't available online and given Covid shipping delays I would have benefited from more of a heads up about how rare some of the books on the syllabus were at the very beginning of the semester so I could have ordered them like months in advance.

I thought that the recorded videos were extremely suited for online learning.  Interactive sections were challenging, though.  I did very much appreciate the flexibility of both lectures and assignments when it came to taking them at a time that was best for students.
Recorded lectures were effective, would have preferred to have more check-in sessions with Prof. Botsman.
The recorded lectures worked very well.
The class ran quite smoothly over Zoom.
The section was small enough that we all had to participate in discussion. Also, the pre-recorded lectures did succeed, I enjoyed them a lot.

Pre-recorded lectures, while decreasing face-time b/w prof and students, was good (in my opinion) because it allowed for flexibility, which was needed this semester, especially with people enrolling from different time zones. Once classes can be held in person again, I think it would probably be better to hear from Prof. Botsman in real-time and in person, but for now that's not possible.

Professor Botsman's lectures were massively successful! Each was a work of art! The live check-in sessions, though they happened less frequently than initially planned, were also great and gave us a chance to talk to Prof. Botsman live, since all the lectures were recorded.
Again, the course delivery was fantastic, especially for remote learning.
I actually really liked the lecture format of being recorded because it allowed the professor to put more time into the presentation and explaining and spelling out complicated terms
Sometimes the lectures were long but otherwise this was pretty effectively adapted to during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Recorded lectures were a really good way, along with the discussion sections.
Recorded lectures were AMAZING. Huge kudos to Professor Botsman for his editing and speaking skills. You could really feel the quality and effort he put into his lectures!

As above, the recorded lectures were fantastic. Virtual discussion sections worked well, although I think that participation was lower than in the typical in-person seminar. This is probably due to the Zoom format.

Asynchronous lecture was much more palatable for the virtual learning environment. Prof Botsman went above and beyond in trying to make them interesting by adding in pictures, funny animations, and interesting factoids. By and far the easiest lectures I've watched. The fact he also actively tried to condense them to be shorter helped a lot too. 

The sections were also good. While each group was quiet, our section leader did a good job of asking the right questions, slowly walking us through the material, and making the readings and discussions interesting.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 10/10 I have already talked this course up to every single person I have talked to this semester about. I looked forward to this every week.
I would recommend this course because Professor Botsman is a great teacher.
Yes, if they wanted to learn more about early Japanese history
Yes, absolutely. This class was incredible and very informative. Prior to the course, I wanted to be a political science major. Afterwards, I'm now planning to become a history major.
Yes. The class goes very in depth into a very interesting time period. If you have an interest in history whether or not you know much about Japan I think this class is worth taking.
Yes.

Yes, I think I would recommend it to those who want to begin to learn about East Asian history. It is so different than other courses I have taken in school, since we usually learn about US or European history. The readings were easy enough to understand and be able to discuss.
Yes interesting

Yes! If you're at all interested in East Asian history, I think this is a great place to start. I've taken a lot of Chinese courses at Yale, but this was a great course for getting a different perspective on East Asia, and I learned a lot about the foundation of current affairs in Asia today (even though this course ends before WWI.) Workload isn't too heavy, so you won't resent the class, but you still get to learn a lot from the lectures, the reading, and the written assignments.

Absolutely! Please take it! Interesting, engaging, not too hard, accessible to people without a background in the area (I'm an MCDB major and my only background was AP World History), plus Professor Botsman is incredible.
I would recommend - a lot of work but I learned a lot
Yes! I would recommend this course to any and all Yale students. I would especially encourage STEM students to take at least one Yale history course before graduation.
Yeah definitely
Yea, it's an interesting course and the workload isn't too bad. The readings are long but deadlines are pretty lenient as well.
Yes, if you are interested in Japanese history.
This was a very interesting and fun class. The readings were also very enticing. Overall this was one of the best courses I took this semester. That is why I would recommend this course.
YES! Professor Botsman is AMAZING and carries the course by itself. I only had a mild interest in the topic, but he made it sooooo very enjoyable and I definitely felt like I learned a lot.
Yes! Fascinating and comprehensive course about Japan during its modernization period.

TAKE THIS COURSE!! Prof Botsman is an ABSOLUTE GEM and I wish he taught more classes at Yale! I couldn't speak highly enough of this course, which I was looking forward to taking ever since I saw it while bluebooking. The course content is incredibly interesting, the professor is amazing, the TAs try to make section engaging, and the workload isn't that bad? Literally the perfect recipe for a great class.
